title: Meet and Eat
description: Time to kick off camp! Join us for some snacks and getting to know your fellow campers!

title: 3D Printer Camp Group – Make One Now!
description: Do you want to build your own 3D Printer?
comment: Hello All, I would be interested in joining in, in either building my own or volunteering. Please let me know if this project is still active.

title: <del>Gettin’ jiggy with the GSM shield</del>
description: The Arduino GSM shield allows you to make and receive voice calls, send and receive SMS messages, and send data over a cellular network.

title: Intro to Python
description: This workshop will serve as an introduction to the Python programming language.  Topics covered will include:

title: Connect iOS & Arduino with Bluetooth LE
description: This is a one hour crash course on how to get your iPhone (or iPad, or iPad touch) to talk to your Arduino using the new Bluetooth Low Energy (aka the Bluetooth 4.0) standard. I’ll look at the various hardware options, and do a “show and tell” with some of the available hardware that I’ll bring along for attendees to look over. I’ll finish off with a live coding demo that’ll walk people through the basics of sending data to and from an Arduino with the classic hardware “Hello World” project; I’ll blink an LED on and off, but this time I’ll do it from my iPhone over Bluetooth LE.

title: Hacking Higher Ed
description: Exciting innovation is happening in the area of higher education. This session will ask participants to look at ways to reinvent higher education to increase its accessibility and exceed the current quality of the experience. We will do a brief survey current experiments such as Udacity, Khan Academic, O’Reilly, Code Academy, Meetups, TED Talks, General Assembly, Hackerspaces.   Topics will talk about new way of thinking about Curriculum, Content,  Conversation, Motivations and Outcomes,  Community,  Physical Space,  Economics, Research to create new institutions for higher education.  These topics are based on the syllabus for this course http://itp.nyu.edu/~dbo3/hack-ed/

title: Arduino 101
description: Learn the very basics of how to program with the popular platform for physical computing projects. If you took the “Hello, Arduino” session on Monday night, this session will cover that information, but also delve deeper into the topics of digital input and output as well as analog input and output.

title: Arduino Programming Basics
description: So if you want to move beyond the blinking LED and learn some more coding for the Arduino, this is the class for you. We’ll review some of the coding from Arduino 101 and then move onto variables, for loops, while loops, and writing your own functions.
comment: Matt, I missed the first Arduino class, shall I take this or wait for another Intro Arduino class?

title: Arduino Programming Basics
description: So if you want to move beyond the blinking LED and learn some more coding for the Arduino, this is the class for you. We’ll review some of the coding from Arduino 101 and then move onto variables, for loops, while loops, and writing your own functions.

title: Now What?! How to turn your prototype into a product
description: When individuals and companies want to bring their product to the market, they run into hurdles like how to source materials, how to access a group of people who will buy it, and how to do it in a way that it doesn’t eat up all their savings and free time. This session is a crash course in the commercialization arc that includes product development, validation, and commercial ramp up.  Issues that arise in these post-prototype stages are important design insights that will make your product idea stronger. We’ll get into practical examples of how to connect with funding sources, user communities, and manufacturers while sharing resources that’ll be ready and waiting once camp is over.
comment: Unfortunately can’t make it, please share any documents/links.

title: Kids Day
description: ITP Camp is a summer camp for adults. But for two hours on June 19th we are going to open the doors to children of all ages. Please sign up for one ticket per child so that we have a sense of how many are coming.
